executive_summary: The need for hotels and motels depends heavily on domestic and international tourism levels, making these businesses susceptible to the overall economic environment. The COVID-19 pandemic's travel restrictions mostly paused travel activity for an extended period of time, causing hotels and motels to be one of the industries hit the hardest in 2020. The lifting of those travel restrictions resulted in skyrocketing hotel revenue in subsequent years but rising inflation pushed some consumers to reduce spending on leisure activities, causing revenue growth to slow down.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Growth continues despite uncertain economic conditions
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: High consumer spending and low unemployment create a positive financial environment for domestic travel, because consumers have more resources to allocate toward discretionary spending. All of this has enabled demand for accommodation to bounce back quickly from the pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Tight Restrictions Limited Travel Activity in 2020
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The United States documented significantly high rates of COVID-19, creating skepticism among travelers at home and abroad and thereby impacting domestic and international travel. This lowered the need for both hotel and short-term rental accommodation.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Hotels Surpassed Prepandemic Average Daily Rates
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Elevated inflation and overall cost of living weakened tourism activity because consumers had less disposable income available for travel and hotel or motel accommodation.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Increasing Regulations on Substitutes Benefit Traditional Accommodations
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A growing number of states aim to protect their local economies by regulating short-term rentals. Local governments support a healthy market by increasing the barriers to offering short-term rentals while boosting hotel traffic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Remote Working Continues to Drive Accommodation Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: During the pandemic, many businesses extended the option to their employees to work remotely, a trend facilitated by technological developments.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economic Uncertainty Will Contribute to Slowing Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Federal Reserve's 11 interest rate increases in 2022 and 2023 have resulted in growing uncertainty among consumers and impacted leisure travel.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Demand for Hotels is Likely to Rise
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: According to the American Hotel and Lodging Association, leisure travel is expected to have reached prepandemic levels in 2023, which will mean increased hotel occupancy rates.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The US dollar is expected to depreciate
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The US dollar is expected to depreciate over the coming years as improving economic conditions at the global level enable other currencies to regain strength. A weaker dollar encourages international tourism by giving travelers comparatively higher purchasing power.

As tourism activity continues to strengthen, hotels and motels are expected to experience an influx of guests, which will enable them to charge higher prices and boost profit. However, these businesses must continue monitoring their costs, regardless of a jump in tourism, as leisure travel is mostly discretionary.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: International Investment Opportunities Are Becoming More Popular
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Since the hotel and motel industry took a major hit during the pandemic, accommodation providers have looked to compensate for losses by creating new investment opportunities, including entering new markets and expanding their existing infrastructure.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry provide short-term lodging in hotels, motor hotels (motels) and resort hotels. Operators may also offer food and beverage services, recreational services, conference room and convention services, laundry services, parking and other services. This industry excludes hotels that have casino facilities attached.
key_trends: Pent-up desire to travel skyrocketed demand for accommodations. As pandemic-related travel restrictions were lifted, more people took previously postponed or newly planned trips domestically and abroad.

Growing economic uncertainty slows down hotel performance. Elevated inflation and subsequent rising interest rates have caused the cost of living to rise, reducing disposable income and discretionary spending.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Domestic travel generates the most revenue in the industry. Common reasons for leisure travel by domestic travelers include visiting friends and family, shopping and fine dining experiences and visiting different landmarks and tourist attractions.

Business trips fell drastically during the pandemic, as most countries curbed nonessential travel to limit the spread of the virus. Online meetings and webinars substituted for business travel as companies also sought to cut costs and reduce exposure to COVID-19.

International tourists primarily come to the United States for shopping, dining, sightseeing, visiting historical places and visiting amusement or theme parks. International travel activity was mostly inactive for nearly two years as the US government enacted travel advisories to limit the spread of COVID-19, focusing mainly on countries with high rates of the disease.

The development of COVID-19 vaccines has enabled in-person events to resume, although rising interest rates have reduced corporate profit, causing many businesses to reduce spending on corporate trips altogether. As more clients request in-person meetings, demand for business travel is likely to expand. Similarly, as the amount of in-person conferences continues to grow, business travel is likely to follow.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Guest room rentals from properties with between 75 and 299 rooms
products_and_services.product_description: Medium-sized hotels with 75 to 299 rooms are often located in small metropolitan areas and close to airports. These hotels offer basic amenities and are more affordable than larger hotels, making them ideal for business travelers and short-term stays.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Guest room rentals from properties with under 75 rooms
products_and_services.product_description: Smaller operators in this industry often offer lower nightly rates, making them an attractive option for budget-conscious travelers like truck drivers and extended-stay guests. Rising disposable income is expected to weaken demand for motels, as consumers will have more resources to allocate toward accommodation.

Hotels with restaurants and bars on site can offer more services to tourists and locals. When choosing a hotel for vacations, some travelers see the availability of fine dining as a selling point. By offering unique services, hotels differentiate themselves in their geographic area, improving their chances in a highly competitive market.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Guest room rentals from properties with over 500 rooms
products_and_services.product_description: Hotels with 300-plus rooms typically include more amenities like swimming pools, children's activities, conference rooms and event spaces. Major hotel brands and franchises can build customer loyalty by offering rewards programs and member benefits. These establishments also often offer partnerships with local tourist attractions.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Guest room rentals from properties with between 300 and 500 rooms
products_and_services.product_description: Hotels with 300-plus rooms typically include more amenities like swimming pools, children's activities, conference rooms and event spaces. Major hotel brands and franchises can build customer loyalty by offering rewards programs and member benefits. These establishments also often offer partnerships with local tourist attractions.

Demand for added services like on-site dining rises alongside disposable income. Similarly, changing consumer trends have shown many tourists prioritize experiences, such as dining, enabling the segment to grow.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Motels were the segment least affected by the pandemic
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Hospitality properties with fewer than 75 rooms are often motels, especially if parking is accessible directly from the room. Motels usually have lower operating costs and can stay open even with low occupancy rates, which helped them to survive the pandemic.

business_locations.location_description: High tourism in the region is attributed to cities such as Miami, FL; Orlando, FL; Key West, FL; Charleston, SC; and Savannah, GA. The region holds various popular beaches and other attractions, such as amusement parks. These factors, when combined with higher temperatures, lead to year-round demand.

Los Angeles, San Francisco and San Diego are popular business and tourist locations due to their beaches, amusement parks and film studios, as well as the headquarters of many companies. The entertainment industry is heavily located in the Los Angeles area, encouraging fans to visit the city. Western cities are popular destinations among travelers from Oceania and Asia, as it is a shorter flight.

The region is home to many national parks, becoming a major tourist attraction, particularly for domestic tourism. Large cities, such as Phoenix, AZ; El Paso, TX; and Las Vegas, NV are highly transited for tourism and business.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Hotels and motels are subject to many regulations, including minimum wage requirements, employee benefits, overtime, working conditions and work permit requirements. Workers in the United States are entitled to no less than $7.25 per hour in 2023.

Locations that offer food services are subject to laws and regulations relating to the preparation and sale of food, including regulations regarding product safety, nutritional content and menu labeling.

Hotels that serve alcoholic beverages must obtain a liquor license from the state where they operate. States control the number of liquor licenses granted, the hours during which hotels can serve alcohol, the price of drinks and the process of disposing of bottles.

The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has increased its powers and regulations on cybersecurity to reduce the risk of data breaches. Currently, no regulations outline the level of cybersecurity a hotel has to implement.

Hotels and motels are required to comply with state and local smoke bans. Smoking is banned in most indoor areas, including restaurants and bars. Although some states allow for highly ventilated indoor smoke rooms, hotels, including guest rooms, are commonly smoke-free environments.
Franchising is regulated at the federal and state levels by the FTC and local agencies. Franchising laws include disclosure, registration and relationship laws.

During the pandemic, hotels were heavily impacted by travel bans and stay-at-home restrictions. Hotels were pushed to offer more thorough cleanings, contactless services and limit room services, among other accommodations, to prevent the spread of the virus.

basis_points.basis_title: Extra services can make a hotel stand out
basis_points.basis_description: Offering a unique experience creates a lure to the hotel, allowing it to grow in popularity.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages costs are driven by onboarding and training
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Hotel employees are largely part-time, low-skilled workers in high rotation, causing elevated training and recruiting costs. Therefore, staff recruitment agencies have become a popular alternative to lower recruitment costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase costs vary based on demand for hotels
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Hotels purchase a broad range of products for consumer use, including sheets, towels, toiletries, TVs, chairs and desks. Similarly, hotels with restaurants and bars have to constantly purchase ingredients and dinnerware, driving purchasing costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Depreciation slows down amid industry trends
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Hotels that own the building face high depreciation costs, accounting for an estimated 8.6% of revenue in 2023. Many hotels have turned to renting or working with investors to mitigate high depreciation costs. As more hotels switch to renting, depreciation spending is expected to fall.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Having to invest in the location of a hotel or motel leads to high levels of capital costs. This, alongside the furniture and electronics across the hotel, drives capital costs even further. The industry also faces a high level of depreciation.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry experienced relatively low volatility before 2020. Following the Great Recession, interest rates reached historically low levels. This trend, alongside improving economic conditions, led to falling economic uncertainty and enabled consumers to plan trips.

Travel restrictions put in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19 caused revenue to drop close to 40.0%. Government travel advisories varied by state but also limited international travel activity, stifling the need for accommodation from both domestic and international guests.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Changes in Macroeconomic Conditions Led to Higher Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: High levels of disposable income and the pent-up desire to travel caused business for hotels and motels to skyrocket once the government lifted pandemic-related travel advisories. This trend initially positively impacted domestic trips and was quickly followed by the recovery in international travel.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations. A low rate does not mean that innovations cannot occur, just that the likelihood of some innovation materializing as a threat is lower. However, the concentration of technologies is high in this industry.

FAQs.question: Does your company leverage free social media platforms, such as Facebook, Twitter and others, to inform and attract new customers?
FAQs.answer: Establishing a direct line of communication to consumers enhances brand loyalty and participation. Moreover, social media use has increased during the coronavirus pandemic and consequently, operators who use social media are likely to benefit from this trend.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales affected by seasonality?
FAQs.answer: Destination hotels that offer off-season promotions and unique services fare better than their direct competitors. However, the summer season is the busiest season for travel in the United States and operators often rely on busy summer seasons to carry them through the year.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities to expand your market share?
FAQs.answer: Increasing scale can enhance consumer access to company establishments and give an edge over the competition by lowering overall costs.

FAQs.question: How does your company provide ancillary services to diversify revenue streams?
FAQs.answer: Operators that anchor a destination bar or restaurant in industry establishments are able to diversify revenue streams and increase demand. Moreover, as consumers seek to limit exposure to the coronavirus, they may be likely to stay in establishments where they can dine and be entertained on the premises.

FAQs.question: Does your establishment offer complementary Wi-Fi to customers?
FAQs.answer: Complimentary amenities is a significant factor for consumers when choosing to stay in an industry establishment. Complimentary Wi-Fi offerings have become commonplace in the industry.

FAQs.question: Does your company leverage mobile booking applications to streamline the booking process?
FAQs.answer: Capitalizing on the rise of Wi-Fi and mobile internet connections increases ease of access to company services.

FAQs.question: Is your company subject to any franchising laws?
FAQs.answer: Franchise laws vary between states and can place limitations on where establishments can locate and how they can compete.

FAQs.question: Is your business subject to varying state laws pertaining to the sale of certain items, such as liquor?
FAQs.answer: Many industry establishments anchor restaurants and bars within their establishments. Therefore, compliance with all municipal, state and federal liquor licensing is crucial.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Hotels experiencing low occupancy during off seasons can increase promotional output or offer ancillary services in order to diversify revenue. Many operators have offered discounted stays during the coronavirus pandemic to boost cash flow. Moreover, operators increasingly offered no penalty for cancellations or changes to reservations during the pandemic to encourage consumers to book stays.

FAQs.question: How does your company's inventory turnover compare to major competitors?
FAQs.answer: Maximizing returns by consistently replenishing inventory can aid in keeping occupancy high. Moreover, operators who cater to budget or lower cost consumers likely bounced back from the coronavirus pandemic faster than operators who offer luxury accommodations as luxury accommodations are more likely to cater to international visitors.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain skilled employees? How do you reward staff who perform well?
FAQs.answer: Access to multiskilled and flexible workforce. Access to multiskilled and well-trained staff is vital to success in the industry.

FAQs.question: How can you improve your company to receive better word-of-mouth recommendations? Do you have any promotions that encourage word-of-mouth referrals?
FAQs.answer: Receiving the benefit of word-of-mouth recommendations. Good word-of-mouth recommendations are quite often the most successful promotional tool. As operators contend with high levels of competition for a smaller tourist base, word of mouth recommendations are likely to increase in importance.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? Does your company keep up to date with the latest technology?
FAQs.answer: Ability to quickly adopt new technology. Successful industry operators need to be able to quickly adopt new technology for the purpose of information, promotions, bookings and reservations. Online reservation systems have become increasingly essential throughout the industry, as consumers increasingly book trips via the internet.

FAQs.question: How have you dealt with competition from alternative lodging? Do you experience high levels of external competition?
FAQs.answer: External competition for the Hotels and Motels Industry. The Hotels and Motels industry experiences competition from lodging alternatives such as RV parks, bed-and-breakfast establishments, room rental services and hostels.

FAQs.question: In what ways will your business benefit from increases in consumer spending? How closely are changes in
FAQs.answer: Consumer spending levels have a direct effect on travel demand. When consumers are spending more overall, they are more likely to spend some of their money on travel and accommodations. Consumer spending is estimated to rise in 2023, benefiting industry operators.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your total revenue comes from domestic travelers? What nearby attractions or destinations draw in travelers?
FAQs.answer: Domestic trips by US residents. Trends in domestic travel, especially business travel, and the total nights spent away from home directly affect demand for accommodation. As the number of trips made by US citizens rises, demand for hotels and motels increases. Operators are anticipated to increasingly depend on domestic travelers as a source of revenue in 2023 as domestic travel has rebounded faster than international travel.
